Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: Cyber-Amplified Bioinspiration in Robotics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
This project mixes results and methods from cognitive psychology, computational vision and learning, neuromechanical systems biology, and robotics to develop a computer assisted environment for studying animal sensorimotor strategies, discovering how they undergird animal cognitive capabilities, and using those insights to inspire new algorithms for robot navigation, localization and situational awareness. We observe live, intact, highly mobile terrestrial invertebrate predators such as ghost crabs, desert scorpions and tiger beetles in carefully constructed habitats that challenge their ability to negotiate terrain and navigate space. We automate the collection, annotation and mathematical model extraction of their behavior from massive, parallel real-time recordings of visual, muscle, neural, and biomechanical recordings. We mine these data sets to develop intuitive hypotheses as well as formal mathematical representations of the basis on which these animals organize their own sensorimotor data streams to compile novel behaviors from previously consolidated constituents in a process of autonomous mental development. We add numerous existing sensor suites to highly agile existing robot bodies and instantiate algorithmically the hypothesized animal models to develop supporting or refuting evidence that challenges and refines them.
Broader Impacts
Scientifically, the new computational tools and ideas we identify in the interrelations we set up promise a bridge between whole areas of disciplines that have long been divided by spatiotemporal scale and the concomitant gap in analytical tradition, terminology and methods. For example, the study of these complex competencies in simpler species offers a new glimpse at the building blocks of cognition in species more closely related to humans. From the perspective of technological invention, algorithms pioneered in this research could lend an animal-like quality to a machine?s proximal tenacity in engaging its environment and even its overall situational awareness within unstructured worlds. For example, the team is inspired to imagine what it might be like to have a search and rescue robot with the (taskable) capabilities of a ghost crab. From the perspective of training and education, the automated database collection and management tools developed in this project bring to a mass audience the conceptual and computational building blocks that have heretofore been the exclusive province of a small group of experts. For example, a universally accessible (?cloud-based?) tool for unifying the design, parsing, display, and cross comparison of robots and animals searchable at will from the most intimate to the broadest scale of design and operation would have a profound impact on the ability of teachers at many different levels to motivate the fascination and unity of both synthetic and biological science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our National Science Foundation’s Cyber-Enabled Discovery and Innovation (CDI) Theme was Understanding Complexity in Natural, Built, and Social Systems. We aimed to bring a cognitive science perspective to animal motor skill learning. We sought to extract and formalize the insights from these animal studies as synthetic hypotheses that could be implemented on physical models (robots) to better understand them and either support or refute their efficacy experimentally. We developed both invertebrate and vertebrate animal models of dynamic obstacle negotiation and manipulation and studied, in tandem, both the concrete motor skills they deployed, as well as, the more abstract situational awareness and tactical decisions they revealed in so doing. At the same time, we aimed to develop a set of physical models (robots) whose bodies could be partially tailored to facilitate transfer of key skill components and whose perceptual suites could also be partially reconfigured and augmented to embody the hypothesized animal behavioral tactics. We built new appendages (tails and flails) for old robots and initiated a major new robot design cycle with the goal of increasing our next generation machines’ motor agility and sensory ability.

Given this unique opportunity to develop novel interdisciplinary collaborations, we achieved significant, publishable results along a number of these objectives, within both the cognitive biomechanics as well as the robotics thrusts of the project. We succeeded in learning a great deal more about the specific animal models than heretofore known. In so doing, the project has given rise to a pioneering synthesis of neuromechanics and cognitive science. We also succeeded in leveraging some of these new discoveries to inspire new, better designs of robot appendages and imbuing the resulting, more advanced robot bodies with commensurately more capable motor behaviors. In so doing, the project has significantly furthered the emerging synthesis of biomechanics and robotics.

Our work impacts the life science disciplines through having pioneered the first synthesis of biomechanics and cognitive science in examining the role of learning motor behavior for complex manipulation and mobility in the unstructured world. Our work impacts computer science and robotics by extracting principles of animal body design and motor behavior for heretofore unachieved machine mobility and then taking the start of further abstracting and extending these principles toward more autonomous landmark based navigation. Our greatest impact outside our principal disciplines is the advancement of Bioinspired Design affecting disciplines as diverse as architecture, art, chemistry, physics, as well as climate change biology and conservation. Our research from the CDI serves as an exemplar for the future of how biomimetics should be conducted. Our impact on human resources was similarly substantial. Over the course of the CDI award, the four faculty PIs collectively funded and supervised training for 4 postdoctoral fellows, 18 graduate students, 76 undergraduate research assistants, 4 high school summer interns, and 1 staff member.

There is a growing awareness in science and technology policy circles of the crucial role for such bioinspired study of embodied intelligence for the advancement of high social impact autonomous robotic technology. The design of human-made devices is now being transformed by principles learned in studies of biological systems and behaviors like those we discovered in our Cyber-Amplified Bioinspiration in Robotics (CABiR) CDI. We are entering an age of innovation inspired by nature. Nature can now instruct scientists and engineers in unexpected ways to design novel materials, devices and algorithms and develop new manufacturing processes, because these emerging technologies capture more and more of the complex features of life. Moving ahead, the next steps along this path will aim these insights toward endowing increasingly sophisticated contemporary robot bodies with the animals’ effortless bodily intelligence. Realizing this potential will make a substantial contribution to society’s need for agile, partially autonomous but safely human-directed sources of programmable physical work.
